comments.author: Daily Spud
comments.content: Had never heard of chimichurri until yesterday and now this is the second post I've seen mentioning it! I'll definitely be bookmarking this one.

comments.author: lisaiscooking
comments.content: Beautiful plate. I love the idea of chimichurri with polenta, and those tostones look fantastic.

comments.author: veggiebelly
comments.content:
We had chimichurri with roasted vegetables on our recent trip to Argentina. Funnily, that was the only time I had chimichurri in the country, and I had to specifically ask for it! I guess because chimichurri is typically served with meat, my vegetarian orders never came with chimichurri.

I love the intensity of the ingredients here, I bet it tasted great with polenta. Youve created a beautiful plate here.

comments.author: Layla
comments.content: Great photo! We had some Argentine neighbors when I was growing up and they would always add a bunch of fresh oregano to their chimichurri sauce.

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Isn't that kind of coincidence odd? Clearly you are meant to make some soon.

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content:
That sounds really good. I like the resinous quality of fresh oregano, it is
totally different from the dried stuff.

comments.author: thepinkpeppercorn
comments.content: That looks and sounds absolutely delicious!!  The sherry vinegar, makes it sound extra enticing - gotta have a kick!

comments.author: Zo
comments.content: Ooo, what a lovely vegan option for a pesto-style thing...thanks for the link!!

comments.author: Hannah @ I Heart Kale
comments.content: I heard on NPR that chimichurri is supposed to be one of the top five flavors of 2009--way to have your finger on the pulse of food culture!

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Nice, for once I'm ahead of the curve :).

comments.author: Tofu Hunter
comments.content: I just got back from a trip to Argentina where I spent a fair bit of time trying to come up with good veggie options that could effectively stand up to chimichurri. I'd often request it along side my pizza, which made a pretty delicious combination, but I think polenta might be an even better idea now that I'm back to my own kitchen. Good thinkin!

comments.author: Otehlia Cassidy
comments.content: Yum! I was just looking for a chimichurri recipe and this looks great. I had one once that seemed to have a sweet-hot flavor as well. Have you ever added sugar?

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content:
<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN">
@Otehlia I've never added sugar to chimichurri... I could see where a very small amount might be good. Sweet/hot would be quite different, I'd have to think about that one!

comments.author: Sue
comments.content: While it's probably not a true chimichurri, there's a vendor at my local farmer's market who sells a "pesto" made without nuts and cheese. Olive oil, parsley, garlic, and chopped serrano chilis. I swear it's the most delicious thing ever... the heat of the chilis is a surprise because you don't expect it.

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Sounds like chimichurri to me! Delicious stuff.

comments.author: Sue
comments.content:
Yeah, that's what I thought. Oddly enough, it's a middle Eastern vendor who sells this, too. Which kinda cracks me up.

They also do olives in the chimichurri... different types of olives mixed in with the sauce. Since the olives are whole, it's hard to eat them but ever so easy to pick out the olives and snack on them, and spread the remaining sauce on bread.

comments.author: kimu
comments.content: I've had a really hard time figuring out how to fit chimmi churri in with vegetarian dishes. I started making it when we were still eating meat and it pairs so well with beef. The polenta idea looks good, any other suggestions on vegetarian dishes that can stand up to the flavor?

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: I think it pairs well with grilled and fried foods, like these zucchini blossoms: https://herbivoracious.com/2010/07/zucchini-stuffed-zucchini-blossoms-recipe.html, or when you want to spice up a more neutral dish like these quinoa cakes: https://herbivoracious.com/2009/07/quinoa-cakes-with-a-farmers-market-feast-recipe.html . It is a powerful flavor, so I'd avoid using it with something that has a subtle flavor that you don't want to obliterate.

comments.author: Donna
comments.content: In Argentina they never use cilantro or capers. This is an alteration from Bobby Flay I think. Cilantro is not indigenous to Argentina. And while I will sometimes chop it in a food processor, I never add the oil until everything is chopped and in my vessel or jar. And in Argentina it is very garlicky so add half a head of garlic instead of 1 clove. Onion is optional! My mother in law would not be caught dead putting onion in her chimichurri. But an Aunt puts a small amount in.  Everyone adds crushed red pepper flakes and fresh oregano is common but I don't use it.

comments.author: Al Zaytouna
comments.content:
Superb Recipe,
This looks just beautiful!

comments.author: Rita Macchietto
comments.content:
My mother-in - law who is Italian used to make a similar sauce, but added chopped red pepper and a little anchovies in it and it was served with meat. Very delicious.
However I make it often just like your recipe and we love it so much. Great on grilled bread and many other uses for it. It's always in my refrigerator. Try mixing in Basil and spread on roasted tomatoes or re peppers on mozzeral. So may things can be made with this. Enhoy
